text:
I want to thank you
all for joining me and our fantastic speakers. Today I have Nigam Shah,

Laurence Baker, Mathew Lungren, Serena Yeung and Tina
Hernandez-Boussard from the AI and healthcare
specialization here with me.

Thank you all for
being with us today. Dr. Nigam Shah is an
associate professor of

medicine (biomedical informatics) at Stanford University, and serves as the
Associate CIO for

data science for
Stanford Health Care. Professor Laurence Baker,
is the Bing Professor of

Human Biology and professor in the Health Policy Group
at Stanford University.

Dr. Lungren is the co-director of the Stanford Center
for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine
and Imaging and

medical school faculty in the Department of Radiology at Stanford University
Medical Center.

Professor Serena Yeung is
an assistant professor of Biomedical Data Science
and by courtesy of

computer science and of electrical engineering
at Stanford University. She's also affiliated with Stanford's Clinical
Excellence Research Center.

As its Associate
Director of Data Science for the Center for Artificial

Intelligence in
Medicine and Imaging. Dr. Hernandez-Boussard, is an associate professor

at Stanford University
in medicine, biomedical informatics,
Biomedical Data Science,
surgery and epidemiology and population health by courtesy. Thank you all for joining us

today and I will now turn it over to Professor Baker to
begin our presentation.

>> Good morning everyone. Let's see, let me get
myself organized here.

I am very excited to be here and to be
able to talk to you all about our program and my
particular part in it.

I am teaching a course on
the health care system in this so the use of

AI and informatics tools
that health care offers huge opportunities to
the health care system

and to developers and innovators. But it's important to come
at this in the context of understanding the
health care system and

how the health care system works. AI and data efforts
more generally interact with health care systems
involving national and regional,

local, even individual
health care providers. The ways that they
provide and finance care in a couple
of important ways.

One is that developers and
innovators need to produce solutions that can help and be of

interest to system participants if they're going to use them. The other way they interact
is that they use data.

Developers, innovators use data from entities that are in
the health care system,

and then they need to understand what the data is and where
the data comes from. [NOISE] We're going to

spend some time
thinking about that, familiarizing you
with the parts of the healthcare system so you can better participate with it,

get some expertise
in what's going on. We go through perspective on a lot of health care systems.

We mostly take the perspective of the US system since there's a lot of complexity
there to work with.

But along the way, we're
going to try to get you up to speed on information and an understanding of
systems that could be

useful in many places
around the world. We spend time in a couple
of different areas.

You see some of them here
on this first slide, there are a wide variety of healthcare providers in the
health care system, doctors,

physician assistants, nurse
practitioners, nurses, technicians, dentists,
ophthalmologists, optometrists,

all sorts of different folks. They work in a lot of
different organizations. You see here I've
got some small ones,

individual physician
clinics where it maybe a couple of physicians
were small practices.

Single hospitals
and all the way up to really large systems
where you see hospitals,

and physicians, and a lot
of different providers, labs, imaging, all in
the same organization.

We're going to try to
unpack that for you, a lot of variety, a lot
of things changing. But what happens when we grow
these larger organizations?

How do they think about data? What kind of data
do they produce? What kind of solutions
do they want? What about the small ones?

We're going to try to
take a look at that. There's been a lot of

interest in trying to understand how that's been happening
in different systems, then these entities
work with payers.

You see the middle of my slide there, private
insurance companies, government organizations,
these folks keep

the funds flowing in a lot of cases and do other
management regulation. We're going to try to
unpack that for you,

so you can get a sense for how these organizations are working
and what they're doing. Then on the right you
see a whole bunch

of other entities
that are out there. They may be government regulators like the Food and
Drug Administration,

the EMA in Europe. They may be pharma or
biotech companies, medical devices, they
may be pharmacies.

There are a whole variety of other entities that produce health care, that produce data, that need innovations from
all of us, all of you all,

to do their job really effectively and provide
really high quality care. Those are the things
we try to figure out.

We're going to look inside
those organizations, what kind of data
is being generated by physicians when they
take care of patients,

that developers and
innovators can use. What about medical records? How those data that
can be extracted from

those might be available
for new innovations. What about payment data? When people send bills
and get money back,

we're going to try to
track how the funds flows. But funds flow between different entities and try
to really get into that,

really interesting and
exciting areas where there's been a lot of change and
a ton of opportunity.

When we get to the end of that, I hope you'll feel like you have a sense for some of these different
organizations,

how they work, what's
been happening? What are the rules and regulations that
they respond to you? Why would they want
your products?

Why would they want
your innovations? How would you make
that work for them? [NOISE] We're also going to
spend some time on pharma.

Pharma is a different
entity if you will. We think a lot
about drug pricing,

drug innovations,
device innovations, drug pricing, and how that works. In this course, after

thinking about other
health care providers, you see a little slide here. We've got to understand how
manufacturers get involved,

drug manufacturers, but then how they send the drugs
around the system. If we want to track
who's using what,

how distributors get involved, we send new products
to distributors, out to retailers like local
pharmacies out to patients.

Data is generated in there
and solutions are needed in there in terms of
understanding what's going on with the distribution,

how to optimize that, how to help patients
get the best medicine. At the same time in the blue, there's a lot of things going on

with pharmacy benefit management with private and public payers
so insurance companies, and the groups that
they work with.

You need to understand some of that if
you're going to try to use data or try
to create stories, or try to get products
that can build off of

the stories of need from
these different areas. You need to know what a
pharmacy benefit manager is, you need to know
what a switch is.

You need to know what some of these different entities are. We're going to try
to tell you that, get you through some of
these areas where you can

understand that the funds flows and the structural flows
in delivering healthcare.

The last thing that
we're going to spend some time on its
quality measurement. In terms of trying to
figure out what's going on

in this particular area we talk about some
of the structures, things people are
trying to measure. We say sometimes structural

measurement is one piece of it. What kind of entities
are out there in the healthcare system
and how are they organized?

Sometimes we think
processes are part of that. What kinds of activities are
people taking to try and improve quality to deliver
the best care to their patients. Then what about outcomes? Do people live longer? Are people made healthy faster?

Can we measure those
kinds of things? Tons of attention to
trying to measure quality and in some of these
different areas produce

data and then process it. Try to understand
what creates quality, what entities are
doing a good job,

what new techniques and I
don't know quantitative work, regulations may drive quality.

Huge opportunities
for people who are interested in the
medical care system, interested in innovations in

order to try to better quality. Lots of data being produced
by these that you can use.

We'll walk through this, we'll try to understand
how these processes work. We'll try to understand
what the opportunities

are and try to set you up to be able to interact
with this part of the health care system and
current efforts as well.

At the end of the day, health care systems
are complicated, but you can understand
the important pieces

of them and you can really get your bearings with respect to the kinds of organizations
that are out there,

what they're trying to do, what kind of data
they're creating and what kinds of solutions
that they want.

We want to provide
that foundation in this course for you. I'm really excited to teach it. Really excited to have you
all interested in this area.

Something that really
I hope can set the stage for the further work in this particular program.

With that, I'm going
to pass it off. That's what my course does. I'm delighted to be
able to talk with you

today and I really hope to
see some of you in the class. [BACKGROUND] >> Dr. Nigam Shah. [OVERLAPPING]

>> Welcome everyone. This class is about
AI in healthcare,

and therefore we begin
with healthcare. One of the major differences for

most of the classes you might experience is that we first introduce what the
healthcare system is.

Lungren described
it in a few slides, but the class will
literally walk you through what's the anatomy,

who does what, what
data do they generate? We need that reference, that context before we
can begin understanding

what we can do with those data using
artificial intelligence. What I'm going to do now is
to give you a little bit of

a preview that assuming you've understood the main parts of
the healthcare ecosystem and

you know the data coming out of the different parts of it, how should we think
about those data?

What are those clinical data that we might get our hands on? For example, imagine this
timeline of a patient,

and I suggest this as a
useful construct to organize the thinking because
multiple entities

in the healthcare system
will produce information, but that information is

tied to a human
being, the patient. What we're seeing on
screen is a cartoon

where we have a timeline
going from left to right, and those little
circles are things that of healthcare consequence
that happened.

Then, underneath that are
the different kinds of data. I've just shown a few examples,

about eight or nine on this one, the diagnoses codes
you might get, the laboratory test
results, medications,

textual documents a
physician might write, streaming data, you
might hear about
genomic data, imaging obviously, which is where AI has a lot of implications and applications,

you might get signals from
bedside monitors and so on. Having this frame of reference of

imagining this
longitudinal record. What happens is that

each different entity
gives you one square. If you have a prescription

that happened at a
particular event, you went to a pharmacy, the pharmacy has a record, the hospital has a
record of ordering it,

the pharmacy switch that
routed it has the record, eventually your insurance
company also has a record.

There's four or five
records of one event, and depending on where
do you get that,

you might even get slightly
different information. That's really important
to understand. We'll walk you through
that. Let's look

a little bit closer. The timeline has
multiple types of data:

diagnoses codes,
laboratory tests results. In the screen, it's hard
to see, but in the class,

we'd actually walk you
through with real examples. I've only shown four
here: lab results,

medications, documents that a doctor might
write, and diagnoses codes.

Then, once we've got and
understood the kinds of data

at our disposal and have organized them into
this conceptual view, then we step into,

what are the questions? That's another
differentiator that, instead of jumping straight to

the AI and machine learning, we first walk you
through the kinds of questions that
need to be answered.
Here's an example. Meet Laura.

She's a teenager with
systemic lupus erythematosus or SLE and presented
when proteinuria,

meaning there's protein in
her urine, has pancreatitis, and is positive for this laboratory test for
antiphospholipid antibodies.

Our goal is to use these
data to provide better care.

In this particular case, what we'll be doing is starting
with all of the patients,

that's that big circle, all our data; we identify those individuals
that are teenagers,
that's the orange circle; those that might have, pancreatitis, proteinuria,

SLE, those are those
other circles. In the end, we get to

the set of patients that
match our description. Now, in this case,
it's hard to see,
but what I've highlighted is this tiny slice of patients that

match all of the criteria for what we're interested in to inform the care of this
particular patient.

Remember, in doing this exercise, we also have to worry
about the time axis, that we have to make sure that

these things happened
in a certain order, and all of those operations and understanding how to do them with

data are probably 80 percent of the work before you get to
the AI and to the modeling.

Time spent here essentially
determines the degree of success in being able to

answer the question that
you seek to answer, and then ultimately gets to improving health care using AI.

To round out this
portion of the course, on the left here on
this particular screen
is a patient timeline, as a compact view with all of the different data types

that we're going to be talking about and summarizes
this yellow block

of patient timelines
because we have these on multiple human beings. Then, we're going to be using

these timelines and
operations on them to basically inform two kinds of

decisions: whether to
treat and how to treat. In the previous example,

the decision to be made was
for a patient like that, we were trying to ascertain,

is the person at high risk
of a thrombotic event, as in getting blood
clots in their feet?

If that risk is high, we would then decide to treat that patient with
anticoagulation.

It's a decision of
whether to treat, also known as risk
stratification, risk estimation.

You can do that
using classifiers, predictors and all sorts of other ways of estimating them.

We're not going to talk
about the decision about how to treat today, but I just want to lay out

these two categories
of questions, both of which can be
informed using AI.

The fundamentals of that are what Doctors Serena Yeung and Mathew Lungren are going
to walk you through.

>> Thanks Nigam.
I'm Mathew Lungren. I'm going to talk
a little bit about

our course along
with Serena Yeung. Our course is entitled
Fundamentals of

Machine Learning in Healthcare. Again, I think a
lot of healthcare,

as we've touched on already, is either focused on
data, information.

We try to take a step
back and say it's not just a hospital encounter or
it's not just one aspect,

it's really the entire
ecosystem together that comprises the playing field

of opportunities for machine
learning in healthcare. But not everybody who is going
to be using these tools or

developing these
tools will have to have deep expertise
in any one area.

In other words, this is a very much
multidisciplinary field.

The purpose behind constructing this course is really
to try to focus

on both the clinical perspective and the computer science or
machine learning perspective.

That's where both Dr.
Yeung and I contribute. Again, this is about
understanding from your domain,

so whether you're in global
health, or you're in pharma, or you're in radiology, or you're in pharmacy,

understanding the concepts and principles behind these tools and technologies such that you
can comfortably evaluate,

potentially contribute to a
team of development project around a use case in

your domain expertise
area or, again, be able to conversationally

understand the inner workings
of a lot of these things that ultimately we
all recognize will be

a major part of
healthcare going forward. Again, that's irrespective of exactly which
discipline you're in.

I happen to be a radiologist, recognizing that I see a lot of applications that are
taking place in my field.

Having the understanding of where these tools will work,
where they won't work,

what biases may be present, how to evaluate them critically, [NOISE] that's really what this course is really going
to help you understand.

Again, the roadmap here is
really taking the larger view,

understanding,
again, your domain, where that intersects
with some of the applications that
exist currently.

But then as you can see here, recognizing that no matter whether you're working
with structured data,

pixel, or imaging data, or with text report,
free-text data,

and other types of
data like Nigam had touched upon in his course, wearables and other
types of genomic data,

you need to find a way to
frame that data and then how it would work within

a given machine
learning construct. Again, this course is really
to give you that background,

arm you with the
expertise so that you can critically
understand, develop,

and analyze these tools in your own area of
expertise, or domain.

That's really the purpose here. You can see here, whether you're working with
structured data, again, pixel data, we need
to boil it down,

and understand which models would work for which
types of data, where those advantages
are, and again,
how to apply them into practice. [NOISE]

>> Hi, everyone.
I'm Serena Yeung. I'm the other co-instructor
for this course. Just continuing from
what Matt was saying,

we'll be spending a
portion of this course introducing the fundamental
computer science concepts

as well behind some of these machine learning
algorithms that can be used,

different types of
prediction tasks on these diverse types of data. We'll cover the fundamentals
that will enable you

to make good decisions used to develop these models
for various types

of AI applications
in health care. There's really a large toolbox of

algorithms that generally
you can pick from. These include both traditional machine
learning algorithms,

such as regression-based methods, decision trees, support
vector machines, and others.
There's also a recent class of a very popular algorithms called deep-learning algorithms,

in particular,
variants as well for visual data, for sequence data.

We're going to cover all of these different types of algorithms, the fundamentals of what
they mean, and importantly,

the trade-offs, and
thinking about how to choose the right model
for your application.

We'll look at trade-offs.
Some of them may have better performance on
certain kinds of tasks.

Other algorithms may
be more interpretable. Some algorithms may
perform better on

certain types of data or
require certain size of data. We'll discuss all of these
different trade-offs,

as you're thinking
about how to choose the right algorithm, and how exactly these
algorithms work.

Then on the flip side, equally important to choosing
the right algorithm, is also being able to
evaluate your models

appropriately once you actually
train your algorithms.

This is a really
important part because different models can perform

differently on
different use cases. Some may be better in
certain scenarios and

others may be better
for other scenarios. Just as one example, for example,

in this graph here, if you have the same, let's say, false positive rate, model A might have better
sensitivity than model B,

and so you might want to
use model A in this case. But let's say you're
willing to take a bit of a higher false positive rate,

let's say in your
screening application, or maybe in this case, Model B actually has better
sensitivity in this case.

The model that you
may prefer to use can really be different
depending on your application.

We're going to go into
these different ways of evaluating these models,

things to think about as well as particular traps that you want to make sure that
you are aware of as well,

some nuance questions such
as biases in the data. We'll talk about the different
pitfalls and how to think

about these questions of
evaluation carefully. >> Ultimately, this is,

again, a multidisciplinary
endeavor. We try to frame this
course with that in mind.

Again, whether your background
is heavily technical, whether your background
is heavily clinical,

or somewhere in between, all across the health
care spectrum, there is value in this
course in learning

about the concepts
and principles that we're trying to outline. Then recognizing at the end
as we tie things together,
how you can build multi-disciplinary teams in order to accomplish your goals. Again, those goals could be

in almost any aspect
of health care, but some of the fundamentals and principles will
remain the same. We're really excited to

present that course
to all of you, and we hope that
you take away from it something that really

impacts your practice
and your careers. I'll turn it over to Tina.

>> What my module does, my module is the final module in the AI and health care course. Really, what I try
and do is build upon

all the other modules that
we've just heard from. In particular, in this module, I present key components of

model evaluation,
deployment, and regulation. One thing I think is
important to understand is

that the majority of AI models developed in health care
end with a publication, a reporting model performance, and generally, they
are not deployed.

In this model, we
tackle other forms of model evaluation that are critical to deployment
or implementation,

that are necessary to prevent unintended consequences of deployed AI solutions
in health care.

In the first lessons,
I provide a framework to better evaluate AI models, a framework that moves
beyond model performance and

highlights the net benefit
of the model to end-users. In this framework, we talk about

understanding the clinical
utility of your model. Who receives the model output?

Who will benefit from
the model output? Is there a mitigating action that could be taken
upon on the output?

Say, for example, I
developed a classifier that identifies cancer patients at

high risk of suicidal tendencies. The care team might
use this model, that's who receives the output,

to allocate additional
social service supports, that's the mitigating action, to help those cancer patients
with suicidal tendencies,
so they are the beneficiaries. The next step in thinking about these evaluations is assessing

the feasibility of a model. Can I get this model
deployed at point-of-care? There's many steps
to thinking about

deployment and the feasibility. Here we review important
questions, such as,

are the data I need
to run the model available in a timely manner and in a translatable format?

What are the
implementation costs? Who is going to actually
work on the IT team to get

this information that I need
in a reasonable time frame? What are the
implementation costs?

Importantly, what are the
post-deployment challenges, thinking about who is going
to be responsible for

the maintenance and monitoring
of the model over time? In the previous example,

as we've identified patients, I think it's cancer patients
with suicidal tendencies, can I get this data and process

it before the patient's
upcoming appointment? Are there enough team members to connect with those patients?

What we don't want to
do is deploy a model and identify patients who might
have suicidal tendencies,

but then not have
the resources or capacity to provide
services to those patients.

Finally, we discussed the
clinical impact of AI solution. This can be measured
in a number of ways,

including improved
patient outcomes, cost savings, reduction
of clinical burden, etc.

Importantly, utility, feasibility,
and impact all need to be assessed before considering

implementation or
deployment of a model. In addition, as I mentioned,

the majority of AI models developed in health care end with a publication and never
get to point-of-care.

This is likely because there are many critical barriers
to deployment. In this class, I discuss
a deployment pathway that

highlights several critical steps that are necessary
for deployment, which starts at the
conception of the idea.

This includes, as others
have said in the course, stakeholder involvement during the design and development state.

Are you asking the
right question that can be answered with
the data you have? A thorough evaluation
of the model

prior to deployment,
including assessing utility, feasibility, and impact,
and a deep understanding of

how the end-user will use this output in your
model is necessary. Finally, we talk
about the need for

prospective evaluation of
the model before going live so you can deploy the
model at point-of-care,

and just view it in
silence how you are predicting patients
and how people
are using that information. Finally, we'll review stages

related to how you would scale your model to address generalizability and
external validity.

Again, a critical
barrier to deployment is the continuous monitoring and maintenance of the
model over time.

Here in this course,
I provide you with insight on how you
can use the output of your model to continuously

improve its clinical
impact and usability. Now, of course, we
can't speak about

model evaluation
without discussing bias and algorithmic fairness. Understanding the
different types of

bias that can infiltrate
into your data, and therefore your model, are essential to help mitigate their effects
in health care delivery.

In this course, I go through
several different types of

bias that can be entered
in the data and we provide some fairness algorithms
to how to mitigate those.

Now, I'm a big fan of
reporting standards such as the Minimal Information For Medical AI Reporting, or MINIMAR.

If the data you use to train
your model are biased, and most likely they are,

or if there are issues with
your model architecture, at a minimum, this
information needs to be
transparently reported so that the end-user or other users know how to implement your model,

know how to apply it to
different populations. Here I discuss the
different types of ways that we can report
these standards and

the type of information
that needs to be reported.

>> Finally, I discuss the regulatory environment for AI solutions in healthcare. Now, this is definitely
a moving field

and quickly evolving, but it's important to
understand the rules and regulations set out by the US Food and Drug
Administration or the

FDA and their aspects
of model regulation. Importantly, in this module,

I highlight FDA's
regulations on software as a medical device and the different pathways
to regulation.

In addition, we discuss the regulation in other
countries, so for example, the European Union and China,

and use that to understand the commonalities and the differences of the
global environment.

At the end of this module, the user should have a
good understanding of how to thoroughly evaluate
an AI solution

beyond model performance in healthcare and
understand a pathway to deployment and
regulation. Thank you.

>> Great. Thank
you so much, Tina. Thank you all of our faculty for

joining us today and for
their presentations. We will move on to the Q&A and

ask our faculty some
questions here. First question is actually
regarding the overall program.

Someone had asked, can
someone join the program even if they don't have a diploma
in a healthcare domain,

but rather in science such
as biology or chemistry? I'm going to leave it
up to you-all to answer

that whoever wants to jump
in and answer that question. >> Well, I'll jump in and should

say from the perspective
of my course. One of the reasons
that we include a course on the healthcare system

in this whole program is that we can get you
that knowledge. If you got a science background,

if you've got a
technical background and you want to work in
the healthcare space, one of the things that I'm
really hoping to do is

give you some exposure to and understanding of the
different entities in healthcare and how they work,

so that you can take your technical knowledge,
and your experience, and your interest
in those areas and apply them to this
particular area.

I'd say, absolutely. Come,
get involved in the program. If you're interested,
we'll try to get you up to speed on the things
that you need to know.

Then as my fellow faculty
carried forward in the program, I think there's also
a lot of exposure

there and in particular to healthcare and how
that might work. I think in a lot of ways, this should be perfect
for you if you're

interested in this
and should really try to give you the
foundation of that. >> Absolutely. Thank you, Loren.

The next question, similar. Is the course suitable
for people who are beginners in programming?

Nigam, you might
want to jump in on this one and share your thoughts. >> Absolutely. [NOISE] This particular
class actually does

not require you to
program yourself. In fact, one of the
things we do in

the final capstone project
is we walk you through, go in step by step,
giving examples,

this is the thing you
would need to learn or do if you were to do
this analyses yourself.

It's a gentle introduction where we first
share the concepts. Well, we first share the why,
then we share the what, and then we get to the how. Then follow on courses

in programming will
then make more sense. Absolutely. I think if there's no prior programming experience,

it should be feasible to enroll and complete this
class successfully. >> Thank you.

>> I just want to
add on to that also. For our discussion of
machine learning algorithms,

it doesn't require
any programming because we're focusing on how these algorithms work

decisions about what
algorithms to choose, and then how to do

then when someone is
trained in the algorithms, how to actually
think about how good

the algorithms are and
then how to deploy them. A lot of the focus is around decision-making with the basic
fundamental understanding

of how the algorithms work. >> Great. Thank
you. Last question

regarding the overall program. Do you have hands-on
sessions in the program for instance do students
actually get to

develop AI solutions
for healthcare?

>> Maybe Tina can take that
regarding the capstone? >> Yes, absolutely.

>> At the end of
the four modules, we develop a capstone course that brings everything together
and provides a use case of how,

and it's actually written in the form of you have somebody
going to their supervisor,

talking about wanting
to deploy a model, and walking through all
of these hurdles that we discuss throughout the
different modules.

It gives the user an
opportunity to really understand where
these barriers arise,

how you can resolve them, and give some real use
case examples of that.

Yes, the capstone project is really well-rounded
across the four modules.

>> Thank you. This
next question here is actually regarding
Loren's presentation.

I think this is regarding
Slide 14, Loren. Someone was asking R or Python?

R or Python? Slide 14. I'm trying to get the
Slide 14 in a minute.

My class doesn't particularly deal with the
programming languages

that you would need to
use or the statistical languages that you would need to use to work on some
of these solutions.

We're trying to get
you an exposure to all the different
